title: Man sues Spanish supermarket over cocaine hidden inside Nesquik
text:
Man sues Spanish supermarket over cocaine hidden inside Nesquik Last updated 16:28, February 13 2017 Supplied 
250gm of cocaine was found inside an innocent looking tin of Nesquik, bought from a Spanish supermarket. 
A Spanish man got way more than he bargained for when he discovered over $19,000 of cocaine stashed in his Nesquik. 
The man, who has remained anonymous, bought the sugary drink powder, among other products, from a supermarket in Zaragoza, northeastern Spain, according to the Spanish newspaper El Mundo . 
A 250g packet of the Class A drug was hidden in a container of the chocolate milkshake powder. 
His suspicions were first aroused when he got home and discovered the container's seal was broken. 
READ MORE: * Tomato sauce: The verdict 
The innocent shopper quickly took his surprise purchase to a local police station where it was confirmed as cocaine. 
The Spanish National Police have launched an investigation into how the narcotic got inside the Nesquik container. 
It has been confirmed the drug was not inserted at the Nestle factory, but it's thought the Nesquik was likely tampered with at the supermarket. 
The man's lawyer, Francisco Javier Acín Viyenta, told El Mundo his client has decided to take legal action and sue the supermarket where he bought the Nesquik for "moral damages" he has suffered. 
Viyenta said his client fears for his safety and is worried he'll face retaliation from drug traffickers. 
Pineapples, coconuts, bananas, furniture, bricks and paintings have all been used to smuggle shipments of cocaine in Spain previously.
